title: Question 85

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for headaches, vomiting, and fever of 5 days' duration. Medical history is notable for a ventriculoperitoneal shunt placed 2 years ago for hydrocephalus following intracranial bleeding. He has hypertension treated with chlorthalidone, losartan, and amlodipine.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.6 °C (101.4 °F); blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg, pulse rate is 98/min, and respiration rate is 18/min. Nuchal rigidity is present. The remainder of the neurologic examination is nonfocal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric treatment?

text.__html: Intravenous ampicillin and ceftriaxone plus shunt removal
Intravenous vancomycin and cefepime plus shunt removal

children: Empiric management of suspected health care–associated ventriculitis or meningitis should include vancomycin and a β-lactam with antipseudomonal activity (such as cefepime or meropenem) and device removal, if present.
The most appropriate management in this patient is intravenous vancomycin and cefepime plus shunt removal (

) and placement of a temporary external ventricular drain. Health care–associated ventriculitis or meningitis (HCAVM) can represent a diagnostic and treatment challenge. It typically occurs after head trauma or a neurosurgical procedure (e.g., craniotomy, lumbar puncture) or secondary to device infection (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid [CSF] shunts or drains, intrathecal pumps, deep brain stimulator).

species and enteric gram-negative bacteria are the most common causes, but up to 50% of patients can have negative cultures because more than 50% receive antibiotic therapy before CSF studies are performed. Worsening mental status, headaches, fever, or stiff neck in a patient who recently underwent surgery or has a shunt should raise suspicion for HCAVM. An elevated CSF lactate level greater than 0.44 mg/dL (4 mmol/L), an elevated CSF procalcitonin level, or both, may be useful for diagnosis when cultures are negative. Empiric therapy should include intravenous vancomycin and a β-lactam with antipseudomonal activity (such as cefepime or meropenem) and device removal, if present. If possible, infected CSF shunts and other devices should be removed because some pathogens form biofilms on prosthetic material and are resistant to antimicrobial treatment. If a causative pathogen is identified, the regimen should be narrowed accordingly.

Intravenous vancomycin and ceftazidime, cefepime, or meropenem are acceptable regimens for the empiric treatment of HCAVM (
), but therapy should also include removal of the infected shunt and placement of a temporary external drain.
No randomized controlled trials demonstrate either the safety or efficacy of intraventricular antibiotics to treat HCAVM (

), and no antibiotics are approved for this indication. Intraventricular administration of antibiotics is potentially toxic but can be used in patients with multidrug-resistant organisms that are not responding to intravenous therapy.

objective.__html: Treat health care–associated ventriculitis or meningitis.
